http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.value: This Data property groups together all of the various reference number properties derived from various catalogues and such. This property can be used by an editor to easily locate all of the possible reference number properties that might need to be used during cataloguing.
Dergé Kangyur and Tengyur reference numbers, from the Tohoku Catalogue
use for city for a Library address
this should be a positive integer indicating the volume of the Work referenced in this Location
The World Bank 2010 population for the Place

An eText created by manual inputting. Input etexts are prepared manually and used to typeset printed versions of texts in the case of many contemporary Tibetan publications. :ItemEtextNonPaginated eTexts generally do not provide alignment with digitized pages.

:ItemEtextNonPaginated generally only have a known relationship to a Work but there is generally not a known page correspondence to the :Item. In some cases, there is no known correspondence to the physical volume structure of the :Work. It may be possible to derive this information later.

This is the main title of a work, the title by which it is the most known. If a work has only one title, it must be of type Bibliographic Title. There should be only one bibliographical title per work.
concatenate with the street number for a Library address

Allows to compose an organization in terms of sub-organizations. Useful for large organizations such as University of California system for which there are many address ranges for each campus such as UC Berkeley and UCLA and so on
organization

:PersonName is one or many authority names of :Person. :PersonName is represented by an rdfs:label and a subclass of :PersonName (which signifies the type of person name). For example: bdr:P1583 a :Person ; :personName [ a bdr:PersonPrimaryName ; rdfs:label "dri med 'od zer"@bo-x-ewts ]

Every :Work should have at least one :workLangScript indicating the primary laguage and script in which the language is presented. There may be more than one :workLangScript when there are multiple languages used for primary text. For example, a dictionary with entries in Chinese, Sanskrit and Tibetan would list all three languages and their corresponding scripts via three :workLangScript statements
Essentially who did the holder receive this :Lineage from
Name of the containing town in Chinese unicode per Karl Ryavec for import of historical Tibetan places
Sites of interest such as monasteries, temples and so on
An event of translating one :Work to another :Work.
A legacy Chinese gis id for the Place provided during migration of historical Tibetan Places by Karl Ryavec and Lex Berman
chgis id
The referenced admin:Outline contains the root-level information from an Outline for this Work

Karl Ryavec supplies the following information regarding this property:

Gonpa per ecumen would be how many temples are there per one sq km of land area minus water, bare rock, ice and so forth.  Thus I totaled the ecumen areas of each township primarily in terms of the sq km of grassland and forests and farmland.  Then because these areas per temple are so tiny I represented the final amounts on my map legend per 1000 sq km so that the numbers would be closer to 1.0 at times.  For example there might only be .0000001 temples per sq km of ecumen.  But if we convert to per 1000 sq km of ecumen we get .0001 temples  which is a more understandable amount.  Though I think most scholars are baffled by technology and so just understand the idea of core areas like the Lhasa valley compared the peripheral areas like the Changthang.  So that's mainly what I focused on showing.
The number of monasteries per ecumen in this Place (presumably a region) from data provided by Karl Ryavec
Used to indicated that a Work has no colophon vs a Work for which the colophon has not been recorded in the metadata.
BDRC is restricting access to the Work.
Place name provided by Karl Ryavec for import of historical Tibetan places
The opening words of the Work
width of the physical item, of this :Work, that is held or scanned in cm

Public Domain Policy
This policy applies only to content in the Public Domain, additional restrictions can apply to Public Domain content, see Restricted Content Policy.

Public domain means, the work has been identified as being free of known restrictions under copyright law, including all related and neighboring rights. You can copy, modify, distribute and perform the work, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.  See https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/mark/1.0/
BDRC’s Public Domain Mark enables works that are no longer restricted by copyright to be marked as such in a standard and simple way, making them easily discoverable and available to others. Many cultural heritage institutions including museums, libraries and other curators are knowledgeable about the copyright status of paintings, books and manuscripts, photographs and other works in their collections, many of which are old and no longer under copyright.  The Public Domain Mark operates as a tag or a label, allowing institutions like those as well as others with such knowledge to communicate that a work is no longer restricted by copyright and can be freely used by others.  The mark can also be an important source of information, allowing others to verify a work’s copyright status and learn more about the work.

Although BDRC does not impose any legally binding conditions on access to the Public Domain content, BDRC requests that it is given attribution as a source of the content, to the extent it is technologically feasible to do so.

Definitions are available in BDRC’s ontology service: http://purl.bdrc.io/resource/LicensePublicDomain 

Copyright Policy
BDRC applies section 108 copyright analyses to its works.

BDRC indicates the copyright status of a book in its Metadata. This status is purely informational and BDRC cannot be held liable of its accuracy.

BDRC considers reproductions (digital images, textual reproductions produced from OCR and manual input) to have the same copyright as the original work.
Some of the content available through BDRC may be governed by local, national, and/or international laws and regulations, and your use of such content is solely at your own risk. You agree to abide by all applicable laws and regulations, including intellectual property laws, in connection with your use of BDRC.

Definitions are available in BDRC’s ontology service: http://purl.bdrc.io/resource/LicenseCopyrighted 

Restricted Access Policy
For content marked as restricted by tradition, you agree to access only content that you have been authorized to access by a lineage holder, and for which you understand the restrictions. You agree to fully respect the conditions under which you have been provided access to the material.

For content marked as restricted in a particular country, you agree not to transfer the material by any mean (paper, electronic) to this country.

For content marked as restricted to scholarly use, you agree not to have.

In addition to other applying restrictions, you agree to share the material solely under the agreement to respect these restrictions.

In addition to licensing, BDRC assigns access designations to works published on its online library at tbrc.org based on cultural commitments to stakeholders. The following access designations are used:
● Restricted Sealed (tib: rgya can) – Some works of the types listed below are restricted because of the nature of their content. The owners of the traditions request these restrictions. Note that if these works appear in the collected works (tib: gsung ‘bum) of the author, they are not restricted as they appear in context.
○ Sealed Texts (tib: bka' rgya ma)
○ Esoteric Collections (tib: be'u 'bum and sngags 'bum)
○ Secret Practice or Oral Instruction (tib: mkhyud dpyad)
○ Tantric Sexual Practice (tib: thabs lam)
○ Secret Sealed (tib: gsang ba rgya can)
○ Secret Biographies (tib: gsang ba'i rnam thar)
○ Ear-Whispered Lineage (tib: snyan brgyud)
○ Esoteric Instructions (tib: khrid yig)
● Temporarily Restricted – works marked as temporarily restricted, until at some time BDRC is instructed to release the restriction. Unless otherwise specified, the time duration is 3 years from the date of publication.
● Restricted by Quality – works marked restricted by quality in cases where the scanned source is of poor quality or incomplete. BDRC reserves the right to restrict access to these works and may direct users to a better quality edition.
● Restricted by BDRC – works marked generally as restricted by BDRC for whatever purpose BDRC deems necessary.
● Restricted in China – works marked restricted where heightened sensitivity in China precludes access in China. Note: these works will be available on our website outside of China.

Specific definitions are available in BDRC’s ontology service: http://purl.bdrc.io/ontology/admin/AccessType 

CC0 Policy
BDRC makes its set of metadata available for public use under the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Designation.

CC0 enables scientists, educators, artists and other creators and owners of copyright- or database-protected content to waive those interests in their works and thereby place them as completely as possible in the public domain, so that others may freely build upon, enhance and reuse the works for any purposes without restriction under copyright or database law.

In contrast to CC’s licenses that allow copyright holders to choose from a range of permissions while retaining their copyright, CC0 empowers yet another choice altogether – the choice to opt out of copyright and database protection, and the exclusive rights automatically granted to creators – the “no rights reserved” alternative to our licenses.

Although BDRC does not impose any legally binding conditions on access to the 
Metadata, BDRC requests that you act in accordance with the following Community 

Norms of BDRC with respect to the Metadata:

First, BDRC requests that it is given attribution as a source of the Metadata, to the extent it is technologically feasible to do so.

Second, BDRC requests that you make the Metadata and any improvements thereto freely available on the same terms as BDRC has done, i.e., without claiming any legal right in, or imposing any legally binding conditions on access to, the Metadata or your improvements, and with a request to act in accordance with these Community Norms.
As a database in the sense of EU Protection of Databases, it is also provided under CC0 license. Extractions of the database of BDRC are considered to be under the same license as the database itself.

Specific definition is available in BDRC’s ontology service: http://purl.bdrc.io/resource/LicenseCC0 

Disclaimer of Warranties and Limitation of Liability

1. BDRC offers content as-is and as-available, and makes no representations or warranties of any kind concerning the content, whether express, implied, statutory, or other. This includes, without limitation, warranties of title, merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose, non-infringement, absence of latent or other defects, accuracy, or the presence or absence of errors, whether or not known or discoverable. Where disclaimers of warranties are not allowed in full or in part, this disclaimer may not apply to you.

2. To the extent possible, in no event will BDRC be liable on any legal theory (including, without limitation, negligence) or otherwise for any direct, special, indirect, incidental, consequential, punitive, exemplary, or other losses, costs, expenses, or damages arising out of use of the content, even if BDRC has been advised of the possibility of such losses, costs, expenses, or damages. Where a limitation of liability is not allowed in full or in part, this limitation may not apply to you.">Terms of Use

Buddhist Digital Resource Center believes strongly in unfettered access to the riches of Buddhist cultural heritage. To enable and enhance this access, we have adopted standardized rights vocabulary developed at Harvard University (http://library.harvard.edu/open-metadata) and RightsStatements.org. Additional access policies defined herein are born out of BDRC’s commitment to stakeholders and are intended to (1) maximize access of Buddhist works to sustain living traditions and (2) protect the legal and cultural rights of Buddhist authors and publishers.  As a public charity, BDRC’s mission is to make the results of its work widely available. BDRC requests that our users, where appropriate, attribute BDRC. The purpose of this Terms of Use is to orient the user on the use of the three central domains of BDRC’s archive: textual resources, metadata and source code.

The latest version of the Terms of Use can be found at:

http://purl.bdrc.io/ontology/admin/TermsOfUse 

Text Resources
BDRC indicates two license types to text resources with several possible access restrictions.  For works whose rights have expired, BDRC uses Public Domain (see Public Domain Policy below). For copyright works, BDRC applies section 108 copyright analyses to its works (see Copyright Policy below). Finally, BDRC applies access restrictions to works based on cultural commitments to authors (see Restricted Access Policy below).
License definitions are available in BDRC’s ontology service: http://purl.bdrc.io/ontology/admin/License. Access definitions are available in BDRC’s ontology service: http://purl.bdrc.io/ontology/admin/AccessType 

Metadata
In order to facilitate use and reuse in machine environments, BDRC makes its metadata available for public use under the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Designation. See CC0 Policy below for more details.  We ask that machine harvesting attribute BDRC wherever possible.  License definitions are available in BDRC’s ontology service: http://purl.bdrc.io/ontology/admin/License 

Source Code
BDRC releases all the source code it produces under free licenses. The licenses vary according to the different software communities, the Apache 2.0 and MIT License are the most used. See BDRC’s code repository for specific licenses used.

Additional Terms
This terms of use agreement (the "Agreement") governs your use of the content available through the Buddhist Digital Resource Center ("BDRC"). When accessing content, you will be presented with the terms of use agreement. If you do not agree to these terms, please do not use the BDRC’s content or its Web site.

Nothing in the Agreement constitutes or may be construed as permission to assert or imply that you are, or that your use of the content is, connected with, or sponsored, endorsed, or granted official status by BDRC.

Some of the content available through BDRC might be deemed offensive, disturbing, pornographic, racist, sexist, bizarre, or otherwise objectionable. BDRC does not endorse or sponsor any content, nor does it guarantee or warrant that the content made available is accurate, complete, noninfringing, or legally accessible in your jurisdiction, and you agree that you are solely responsible for abiding by all laws and regulations that may be applicable to the viewing of the content.

You agree to indemnify and hold harmless BDRC and its parents, subsidiaries, affiliates, agents, officers, directors, and employees from and against any and all liability, loss, claims, damages, costs, and/or actions (including attorneys’ fees) arising from your use of its content and services. You agree that this Agreement is governed by Massachusetts law and that any suit arising from this Agreement will be brought in Boston, Massachusetts, and you further agree that on the election and reasonable notice of either party any litigation shall be referred to arbitration pursuant to the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure. In addition, you agree that should any provision in the Agreement be found invalid, unlawful, or unenforceable, that provision shall not affect the validity or enforceability of the remaining provisions.

BDRC may immediately terminate this Agreement at its sole discretion at any time upon written notice (including via email) to you. Upon termination, you agree that 

BDRC may immediately deactivate any password it has issued to you and bar you from accessing its content. 

BDRC may modify this Agreement from time to time, and your continued use of the content constitutes your acceptance of any and all modifications. BDRC will attempt to notify you of substantial modifications via the email address that you have registered with us, if any.

We welcome your input. Please contact us with any comments or questions at inquiry
Individuals of type adm:TermsOfUse are statements regarding the intended uses that may be made of a class of resources
The longitude of the Place
An assertion represents a statement made in a source. It contains a comment summarizing the statement in plain language and a location indicating the source.
The page in the volume of the Work indicated by the other statements for this :WorkLocation
The line on the page that is referenced
when a work is known by different titles, the main one is recorded by :WorkBibliographicalTitle and the others with :WorkOtherTitle. This should mainly be used with abstract works.
The referenced work is a derivative of this work. This means that the referenced work may be a later edition or a version with some "corrections"/changes to the content of the referenced work.
Ganden (dga’ ldan) or “Golden Manuscript” (gser bris ma) Tengyur reference number

The following explains the intent of splitting an Outline into chunks when outlining very large works. This is why there is a <o:location/> element spec'd in the outline.xsd; however, this feature has not been used in this manner but rather as a redundant marker of which work is being outlined. In the case that the Outline is the detail of a particular Text then the location typically will specify the Work and Volume (relative to 1) that contains the Outlined Text. Thus Locations on the sub-structure need only mention page, line and phrase

The WorkLocation describes the Work, Volume, Page and so on at which something of interest occurs, e.g., the beginning or end of a Work that is contained in another Work; or a reference to the source of a Lineage
parent facet of Work locations by page and folio. The XSD defn is located in common.xsd but is move to Work in the new ontology since that is a more appropriate location
The latitude of the Place

Blank nodes of this class collect together the various reference numbers that apply to a given work. This is primarily used in Kanjurs and Tengyurs for which there are quite a number of different catalogue number schemes.
Works in the Public Domain. Creative materials that are not protected by intellectual property laws such as copyright, trademark, or patent laws.
The type of online access permitted for the subject Work.

A comma separated list of image indexes that are missing. For example:

    :imagesMissing "43,77-78,192'

This is a rare situation but needs to be handled.
The num attribute records the last RID suffix allocated for the Library. The num should be a 6 digit zero filled string initialized to "000001".
Explanation of the update

adm:Entity is an administrative entity in the BDRC ontology. Administrative entities are not the subject matter entities that the BDRC ontology entities are "about". Rather, they are entities that are used to manage the BUDA information system.

The librarian property records the name of the group of users that are permitted to add/update/delete Library holdings. The group name will conventionally be named by lower-casing the TLM/code and appending "librarian". for example, "dzllibrarian"
Migration hint: use also for <o:description type="extent"/>
A statement of the extent of the Work
If true then the location is specified in terms of folio # and side: verso/recto
Migration hint: When not empty the <pubinfo:volumes/> is a note regarding how many and which volumes have been acquired, scanned and so on.
From Paul Hackett's catalogue
From CBETA
Indicates that another Topic is related in someway to this Topic. Eventually this will need to be clarified in terms of prior practice
refers to the ending volume by name, e.g., ca, ta, nga
The ending line on the ending page that is referenced
the material on which the content is imposed: palm leaf, digital, paper etc
Where and by whom the Work was scanned (or requested to be scanned)
Migration info: The <work:info @parent/> should be migrated as :workExpressionOf

Friend of a Friend (FOAF) is a project devoted to linking people and information using the Web. Regardless of whether information is in people's heads, in physical or digital documents, or in the form of factual data, it can be linked. FOAF classes used in the BDRC ontology are used primarily for administrative purposes since FOAF is not itself a cultural heritage vocabulary.
Used to represent a mispelling of a label that is otherwise intended to be retained in the dataset
Used to hold various root-level Outline information that has no place in the constituent Works.
Exception notes such a missing volume, damage to pages and so on

Migration hint: occurrences of this event in the legacy data are modeled by adding a PlaceEvent of type founded to the Monastery Place and a reference to the founder Person via :placeEventWho predicate

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#deprecated.value: this Person event is deprecated in favor of modeling via PlaceEvent

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.value: Catalog of the Tucci Tibetan fund in the library of ISMEO
Migration hint: the name from the outline. This should be the bibliographic name of the Work being outlined but apparently isn't always.
adm:Facet is a facet of an administrative entity in the BDRC ontology.
from Mibu's catalogue
Individuals represent various (Tibetan) Buddhist traditions
length of the physical item, of this :Work, that is held or scanned in cm

The :lineageRef identifies another :Lineage that is an alternative version of the current :Lineage. In gsan yig and thob yig there can be references to different versions of how a given object has been transmitted up to the time of the writing of the gsan/thob yig.
Names are represented by rdfs:label

A collection of Works that are distributed together. Historically this has meant on a CDROM, DVDROM or hard drive. Nowadays, Products are used mostly to collect Works that are made available to institutional subscribers online via IP-address validation. Although there are still hard drive collections prepared from Products.

IP-address validation is supported by adding to a Product sets of address ranges organized by organizations, like UCB, TUMS etc. When the migration ontology is normalized these sets of address ranges should be given their own resource outside of the Product resource since the model of institutional subscriptions is being changed so that it is not Product centric.

Products have decs:contents rather than a :name (but this can be added during normalization). 

The various Works that are contained in the Product include an inProduct element that refers back to the Product. So to find all the Works that are contained in a Product is a simple query. to locate all Works that refer to a given Product via wrk:inProduct.
The contents of the Work are freely avaiable in their entirety.
Identifies a Place that this Place contains.
A content provider is a source of content (images or metadata)
The Work is not to be made available in the PRC.
This property is applicable to Persons and Topics (that represent deities or other ahistorical figures).
Narthang Kangyur and Tengyur reference number, from Eimer's catalogue
the type of content: manuscript, blockprint, etc

this annotation indicates that the annotated property is to be converted to some other expression, typically to a form that is expressed in terms of a common 3rd-party ontology such as bibframe or foaf.

The value of this property should be an explanation of the needed conversion as an rdf:langString
A transliteration for a :LangScript. Mostly this will apply for Pali situations since texts are always written in a transliteration of Pali in a Romanization or script of a language such as Thai.
A statement of the authorship of the outline of this Work
Migration hint: use this for <outline:creator/>

Use this property to reflect a label/name for a "synthetic" part of a work such as "Sutra Basket" or "Guhyagarbha Commentaries" that is not identified directly in a composite work such Kangyur or Kama but that helps to highight the organization of composite work
Places of unspecified type
Log entries for :Entity updates. Includes the agent, date and message explaing the update.
Migration hint: The source person.xsd includes event/pid which is not used and should be silently discarded during migration.

A Person Event describes place, date and other relevant information related to some significant event such as ordination, marriage, birth, death and so on.

The type of event is represented as a subclass of :PersonEvent
The preferred human-readable label for a resource. For a Work this is typically the bibliographic title and will be repeated in a WorkTitle, similarly for Persons
Identifies a Taxonomy that specifies the Library's shelf classification. By convention the taxonomy should have maximum depth of 4 levels - this constraint allows for a manageable GUI design.

If :workLocationByFolio true then end side should be either "recto" or "verso" but will likely need to be normalized since there has not been validation in the editor of this field. Most locations are specified in terms of pages.

A slice of text is specified by starting chunk and char, and ending chunk and char.

Slices are used to identify portions of an Etext for any purpose, such as pages, lines, parts-of-speech; or a semantic textual structure such as a chapter or paragraph and so on.

Types of slices may be identified as subclasses of :EtextSlice, such as :EtextLine and :EtextPage.
Identifies the type of :Lineage such as empowerment, reading transmission, various sorts of instructions and so on
The Names of individual Corporations are represented by rdfs:label
Corporation defines important social institutions in Tibet that (1) owned land and (2) had members. Examples include families and monastic institutions
This :Work is included in the referenced admin:Product
Indicates that the annotated property is to be converted directly to a statement in terms of another property. The value of this annotation is the target property to convert to.
Lhasa Kanjur reference number
The Etext is the entire volume
The script for a :LangScript
refers to an :EtextRef that identifies an :Etext and the position of that :Etext in a containing :VolumeEtextAsset
A statement of the location of this Work in a containing Work or of the pagination present in the text versus the formal location in terms of page images.
Use this title for the cover page titles when they differ from the bibliographical title.

The admin property records the name of the group of users that are permitted to update the Library and Monastery profiles for the Library. The group name will conventionally be named by lower-casing the hasTLM_code property value and appending "Admin". For example, "dzlAdmin"
The Library (Place) that contains the physical holding
When, where and by whom production of a :Work was completed
The Gender Type records the gender of a :Person if known. If the gender is not known, then bdr:GenderNotSpecified is used.
From Imaeda's catalogue
The type of Place: monastery, river, mountain pass, etc.
Place ID assigned by Lex Berman used for import of historical Tibetan place information. This id is based on an old GB code and is not current. It will be removed in the future from the data set
Library of Congress Control Number that identifies a resource description.
Natural features such as rivers, caves, mountain passes and so on
Identifies where the holding is shelved. The shelf code is based on a library specific taxonomy

Migration hint: For physical items in the FPL - note there is both a physical item and an image asset item for FPL - the string value for the :itemHoldingShelf is formed by concatenation:

    desc_room + ' | ' + desc_id
Refers to the Library of Congress Shelf mark call number

http://purl.bdrc.io/ontology/admin/conve.value: convert to Bibframe identifiedBy with range Bibframe ShelfMarkLcc class

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.value: Total number of pages in the volume

This was the description of type colophon which was used primarily (exclusively?) on <outline:node/>s. It is now part of the extended bibliographic model allowing to tag any sort of Work with a colophon
Use this type for titles in table of contents when they differ from the bibliographical title.
The integer id serves to order the chunks of an Etext
this property is used to migrate the venue attribute from scanrequest. it records where the scanning was to take place
Names are represented by rdfs:label

Places are geographic entities ranging from monasteries, to villages, to counties, provinces and so on. Places are modeled in terms of subclasses that indicate the type of "real world" place that is referred to
The 2013 Chinese GB code for the Place. Similar to U.S. Zipcode

The location within an :Etext of a character within an chunk. The location is a subtype of xsd:string constructed by concatenating:

    chunk number + ":" + char number within chunk

Both chunk and char number start at one.

The accession attribute records the next accession number to be allocated for the Library. The num should be a 6 digit zero filled string initialized to "000001". This number is incremented each time a new holdng is added for this library.
Refers to an :Etext that is contained in a particular :VolumeEtextAsset
A note regarding a bibliographic feature of the Work
a :Work which content was produced by a method consisting of a relief process in which a design is cut into and printed from the surface of a wood block
Log entry for updates to BDRC resources
The Work is sealed by tradition.
An event of copying a :Work by some means such as manual enscribing, photocopying, etc.
This class is used for the body of annotations related with RDF statements.
Refers to a line of an Etext page

The subject work is a reproduction of the referenced work such as a photocopy or a an offset print of an original or photocopy and so on. This is relevant to record versus :workExpressionOf when there may be features peculariar to the fact of reproduction versus a direct production such as from master woodblocks or, in a more modern setting, the original offset plates from an input text.

For example,

bdr:W22084 :workReproductionOf bdr:W9NEW01

indicates that bdr:W22084 is considered to be scanned images from a reproduction of the conceptual sdg dge Kanjur identified here as bdr:W9NEW01. The bdr:W9NEW01 denotes the constellation of versions/reproductions and derivatives of the (mythical) sde dge Kanjur.
This refers to a :Work that the subject :LineageHolder authored as an element of the :Lineage - a commentary of some sort typically

Indicates that this Place is near to another - typically because of some reference in a document. In other words, there is some textual reason for mentioning the nearness; otherwise, the metadata could be filled with gratuitous nearness assertions.

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#deprecated.value: not actually used in legacy data and not well defined

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.value: When, where and by whom a :Work as requested to be produced
Migration info: This is the <work:info @nodeType/> attribute NOT the unused @type attribute
Shelf mark based on Library of Congress Classification.
The number of the volume in the Item. There is no implied order in RDF and there may be missing volumes so it is necessary to explicitly indicate the volume number.
used with a :Work which content was handwritten and that through some unspecified sequence of further copying actions came to be scanned

There are subclasses of Volume corresponding to the different types of holding: physical, digitized images, and unicode etexts.

Each :Volume corresponds to a volume an associated :Work. A :Volume may have a :onDisk property present when the Volume has been digitized and deposited in the online archive.
Subclasses of bf:Thing are BIBFRAME classes that are referred to in the BDRC ontology

:workHasRoot is typically "inferred" via a path expression such as:

    ?hEx bdo:workPartOf+ ?hExW .
    optional { ?hExW bdo:workPartOf ?hExWP }
    FILTER (!bound(?hExWP))
    ?hExW skos:prefLabel ?hExO .

which can then be constructed to:

    ?hEx :workHasRoot ?hExW .

rather than storing the triple explicitly for every part of a large composite :Work such as a Kanjur or Tengyur.

Adding this "virtual" property to the ontology provides a place to add the labels needed to localization of applications
The referenced work is identified as a translation of the subject work. This will be used, for example, when the referenced work is a Tibetan translation of a subject Sanskrit work.
Refers to the International Standard Book Number for the Work

http://purl.bdrc.io/ontology/admin/conve.value: convert to Bibframe identifiedBy with range Bibframe Isbn class

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.value: map the country for a Library address
Ending chunk:char of a page, line, or other slice
Migration hint: the @location of the <x:note/>.
A location statement for where in the :noteWork to look for the :noteText
This Item is for the referenced Work, i.e., this Item represents a physical or digital instance of the referenced Work
The admin email is used to send requests for new users to be added to the Library.
The type of Work - from legacy metadata: publishedWork, unicodeText, etc. This is from the <work:info @nodeType/>
The Work is temporarily restricted.

personIsIncarnation records which being (Person or Topic) this individual is an incarnation of and optionally what sort of incarnation (body speech, mind, etc). There are 1,456 individuals out of 18,320, that are marked as being incarnations of some being. Of these, 18 are marked with per:incarnationOf_relation and 5 are marked with per:incarnationOf_secondary.
Various kinds of semi-formal and historical references to extended geographic areas such as administrative districts, isolated areas, premodern counties and so on.
A comment about the subject resource, possibly with a source Work and a location in the Work
An old GB code for the district containing this place from import of historical Tibetan places by Karl Ryavec and Lex Beerman
Refers to the Tradition that the place event is affiliated with.
Indicates that two Works contents are similar to one another

Entities used from VCARD, primarily for contemporary addresses. VCARD provides am appropriate vocabulary for expressing the address information associated with Libraries in the TLM project,among other cases where physical addresses are modeled.
True if this Work is part of a series. In which case it should have a :workSeriesNumber
refers to a volume description which could be a digital asset, scanned or etext; or a physical volume (part of a physical holding)
A :seqNum may be a page number, line number or other id as appropriate to the use of the :EtextSlice or other contexts such as the sequence of eTexts in a Volume and so on.
Names are represented by rdfs:label
Roles include offices held as well as other positions. Roles was formerly called Office in the tbrc.org XML schema. Roles is prefered as a more commonly concept in libraries.
The terms of use of the metadata shoud be spelled out here
Migration hint: Used only in O01CT0001 to record some sort of date information from the colophons of various texts. The format is non-standard will require further examination
A script in which a language is written. For example, DbuCan, DbuMed, Kyug'Yig, Native (implies Unicode)
:Facets are essentially n-ary relations that apply to one or more Resources. Facets are compound features or properties of Resources.

If :workLocationByFolio true then side should be either "recto" or "verso" but will likely need to be normalized since there has not been validation in the editor of this field. Most locations are specified in terms of pages.
A free-text statement of the holdings by BDRC of this Item (and its relatives).

Migration hint: the <pubinfo:tbrcHoldings/> should be mapped to :itemBDRCHoldingStatement on the associated Item.

This might require creating an otherwise empty Item to stand-in for a Work that has yet to be scanned.

The :workOtherLangScript is used to indicate language script combinations that occur in secondary or subsidiary roles within a :Work. For example, a preface in Chinese for a primary Tibetan text could be indicated via:

    :workOtherLangScript bdr:ZhNative

or a text containing handwritten comments in Tibetan might have:

    :workOtherLangScript bdr:BoKhyugYig
Use this title type for titles that appear specifically in the colophon when they differ from the main title.

Identifies a Place that this Place is located in - usually a single Place but to account for changes over time in the definitions of regions and such it may be necessary to have multiple associations.

As a convention in the BDRC ontology, use rdfs:comment for summary and contents statements about a resource rather than adding additional properties.

We take the view that the summary or contents statements can be treated in a manner similar to the use of rdfs:label as a way of providing a short description of a resource
Another version of the name of the containing town per Karl Ryavec
facsimile

the :workPartTreeIndex is a dotted list of indexes of the part among its siblings under each parent up to the root. For exmaple, suppose a part is the second part under the third part under the first part under the fifth part under the root work then the index will be:

    5.1.3.2

so go to the fifth child of the root then to the first of its children, then to the third child of that and finally to that child's second child

Types are used to indicate features names, titles, events and so on.

An owl:subClassOf :Type, e.g., :KinType, will have some set of individuals that represent the various types, e.g., bdr:KinUncle, bdr:KinYoungerSister, etc.

The set of such individuals may be further organized via :Taxonomy but need not be.
This combination is extremely rare but at least one occurence was found.

The original corporation.xsd includes several attributes on <region/>: @start, @startCirca, @end, @endCirca that are not used except in one case 
for @start, C71, and a different instance, C13, for @endCirca. The uses are not correct and these attributes have not been included in the current model.

Thus crp:region maps crp:Corporation directly to plc:Place without any additional chaff
This property records a Place characterizing the region in which the Corporation occured/occurs.

Entities are the principle types or concepts in the BDRC ontology. Individuals of type subclass of :Entity will correspond to distinct individuals in the domain of discourse of BDRC, such as Persons, Places, and Works.

Indicates whether the outlining is relative or absolute. This refers to the convention for WorkLocation information. Almost all outlining is done with absolute pagination.

Relative pagination uses pagination in the content of the work while absolute counts from the first image of a scanned volume an since there are 2 scanned pages of metadata in each volume, absolute pagination generally starts at 3.

Migration info: The pagination information affects the interpretation of the :WorkLocation(s) that occur in the original outline. The migration should add the pagination information to each WorkLocation since there will no longer be an Outline document
records the legacy outline type
this property is migrated from the pubinfo.xsd and is sparsely used in the xml dataset (546 occurrences).

:Item captures the structural and administrative metadata associated with a digital or physical asset. While the BDRC ontology is primarily concerned with digital assets of texts, :Item could easily be extended to other types of digital assets (as is the case with the Tibetan International Digital Library collaboration) such as audio and video, as well as physical assets, such as the physical holdings of monastic libraries.

The :Item resource collects info from migrated ImageGroups and ScanRequests.  An :Item is a collection of :Volume components (i.e ImageGroups).  A ScanRequest for the Work associated with an :Item is migrated as :scan_venue, and the instructions note (if any) in the ScanRequest. The @work attribute of the ScanRequest refers to the Work of the corresponding volume. All other fields of ScanRequest are ignored for the migration.
use for titles indicated on the spine of a book when it differs from the bibliographical title.
A variant label for entities such as :Place, :Corporation and so on
The number of volumes in the item
Migration hint: Used to migrate the log entries from Outlines that are being converted to many individual works

This should be a positive integer counting from the left side of the page tshegs and shads to the phrase (syllable) that is to be indicated by the location. This is optional and only makes sense if there is a :workLocationEndLine specified as well.
adm:Type is a type used in the implementation of an administrative entity in the BDRC ontology.
An identifer, typically a Tibetan letter, indicating the position of the text in a sequence of texts. Conventionally appearing in a side box of the textbox
A page of Etext corresponding to a physical/image page. Specified with a page id, starting chunk and char, and ending chunbk and char

A description of the physical appearance of a Volume of the Item. For example,

"No covers. Gilded leaves with vermilion band. Printed cotton wrapper with floral designs."@en
Migration hint: for FPL Works map the <work:description type="remarks"/>to :volumePhysicalDescription with string with language tag "en"
Authorship statement for the Work.
Migration hint: Use this when migrating <o:description type="authorship"/>
who performed the updated being logged
This script is not normalized in ISO 15924 (yet?)
The object of this property is an xsd:string representing a geoJSON Polygon or Mulit-Polygon. See http://geojson.org/geojson-spec.html
The source Work for the noteContent
Indicates a statement of error in the content

This should be a positive integer counting from the left side of the page tshegs and shads to the phrase (syllable) that is to be indicated by the location. This is optional and only makes sense if there is a :workLocationLine specified as well.
Creative Commons BY-SA 4.0 Unported
records the chapters of a larger Work contained in this Work
Migration hint: <o:description type="chapters"/>

BDRC applies a section 108 copyright analysis to Works in its archive. Copyright protects works from being copied and distributed and varies by country: In the US, the right to copy is held 70 years after the death of the author, 50 years after the death of the author in China, and so on.
An event of some type that occurred at the subject Place around some date, involving some Persons and other entities: founding, destruction etc.

Indicates that this Work is a member of a series. This property is used rather than :workPartOf to distinguish between the situation in which a series is typically not published all at once versus a collection of Works such as a Kanjur or gSungbum that is conventionally published and distributed all at once.

Migration hint: Use this when a Work has <w:info number="?" parent="Wxxx"/> via:

bdr:Wwww :workNumberOf bdr:Wxxx .
The ending page in the volume of the Work indicated by the other statements for this :WorkLocation
The regex is does not take into account opitional blank, ' ', or dash, '-', chars separating the various groups. Also there is no spec for calculating the check digit
The event is known to have occurred during the year given
Physical assets are indicated for libraries that are register their holdings in the BUDA dataset
An event of printing one or more :Items of a :Work

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#lab.value: The work is made available under Creative Commons, CC0 1.0.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.value: used with a Series to reference a number of the series
The components of the address for a physical location.
This is the number of this Work in a series - implies that this work is a part (member of) a series Work.
pages of text content in the volume

A unit of organization for IP-address based access control, e.g., the University of California System, PR99UCS01. A ProductOrg may have zero or more ProductOrg members, via productHasOrg, to allow for organizing large multi-level organizations such as the U. California system. Also a ProductOrg may have zero or more productHasAllow assertions to indicate IP address ranges that are allowed access.
The name of a ProductOrg is represented by rdfs:label
Names are represented by rdfs:label

Subjects Just as in a traditional library catalog, each Work in the knowledgebase can be classified under one or more Subject Headings. A Subject Heading can be one of the following things: 1. A technical term; 2. The title of a Work; 3. The name of a Person; 4. The name of a Place. A technical term (e.g. mandala or sgrub thabs can have any number of Equivalent Meanings from other languages. The other types of Subject Headings (Work Titles, Person Names, Place Names) are also Library Objects with their own records in the Works, Persons, or Places databases. Each Subject Headings record is composed of several fields. Not every field appears in each record. Click on the links below for more information about these fields. Subtopics: Subject Headings that are connected to Works Subject Headings with equivalent meanings Subject Headings Usage Information See also: Library Objects | Subject Search
The topic.xsd <seeAlso/> is model via the top:seeAlso annotation property

License describes the legal standing of copyright for the Work.  BDRC applies a section 108 copyright analysis to Works in its archive. Copyright protects works from being copied and distributed and varies by country: In the US, the right to copy is held 70 years after the death of the author, 50 years after the death of the author in China, and so on. If the Work is not under copyright protection, BDRC applies CCBY, PublicDomain, or Mixed as needed. Note: texts produced by electronic input are generally not considered protected by copyright.
University of Vienna, resources for Kanjur and Tanjur studies (rKTs) reference number for Kangyur texts

A :WorkSite describes where some activity associated with a Work occurred. This was a component of the Outline nodes but has been folded into the general bibliographic model applicable to all :Work(s)

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#deprecated.value: deprecated in favor of the various :WorkEvents.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.value: The value is the legacy Outline Node RID so that redirection can be implemented for purls referencing nodes on the old www.tbrc.org site.
digital material for content which is held in digital format in the archive (:Etexts)
When, where and by whom the production of a :Work was originated
Terms of use for scanned images goes here
this should be a positive integer indicating the ending volume (if different from the starting volume) of the Work referenced in this Location

the :note annotation adds language tagged string and optionally a reference to a Work and a simpe text description of a location in a Work, e.g., "pp. 231-3".

In the XML db the notes are restricted to a limited set of items such as top-level resources and Outline Nodes, Place Events and so on. In this model there are no limitations on where notes can be attached. They can be attached directly to any owl:NamedIndividual or property. In particular one could add a note to the per:name property on an individual that provides evidence for the particular per:name assertion.

The most basic class in the BUDA ontology is owl:thing. Subclasses of owl:thing are (1) the principle concepts (:Entity) that constitute BUDA's domain of discourse, (2) facets (n-ary properties) of the principle concepts, (3) features of an :Entity or :Facet, such the types of resources such as place events, work titles, or features such as WorkTitles, and (4) relevant classes from third party ontologies that BDRC refers to in constructing concepts, facets and types.
May indicate language and script information about the content of the Work

The Agent class is useful in a few places in FOAF where Person would have been overly specific. For example, the IM chat ID properties such as jabberID are typically associated with people, but sometimes belong to software bots. The Agent class is the class of agents things that do stuff. A well known sub-class is Person, representing people. Other kinds of agents include Organization and Group.
A description of the what, when and where of an event in the life of a work

:LangScript individuals represent combinations of a Language, a script, and possibly a transliteration in which the Language is expressed. For example, bdr:BoEwts represents Tibetan in the Extended Wylie transliteration (which is written in Latin script)

Only limitted access is allowed. The typical case is a copyrighted work, for which a small portion of the contents can be made available under the exception for libraries and archives. In the US, this is rules by section 108 of the copyright law.
The number of monasteries per 1000 sq km in this Place (presumably a region) from data provided by Karl Ryavec
Legacy outline type
The license under which access to the metadata representation of the :Entity resource is provided
refers to the volume by name, e.g., ca, ta, nga

Rules should be added to indicate that :taxElementOf and :taxSubClass should be used with a "coherent" set of individuals of some :Type. In other words the set of individuals related among themselves and a :Taxonomy individual should be all of the same :Type (or maybe family of types).

Futher there should be inference rules for :taxElementOf and :taxSubClass so that queries for bdr:TraditionDrukpaKagyu find also instances of bdr:TraditionTodrukKagyu and so on.
A natural Language such as bdr:Bo for Tibetan, bdr:Zh for Chinese, bdr:Sa for Sanskrit, etc.

An eText created via OCR or manual input where pagination has been maintained in the eText of a set of digitized page images.

Paginated etexts are searchable Unicode documents that correspond to image assets in BUDA. Paginated etexts are primarily used as searchable metadata that can help to identify digitized images of interest. These texts should not be expected to be error-free but rather treated as hints providing access to the image archive. :ItemEtextPaginated have known pagination correspondence to an :ItemImageAsset from which they are derived.

In some cases, such as texts from the Asian Classics Input Project (ACIP), pagination information is maintained in the :ItemEtextPaginated, even though there might not be a known correspondence to the image asset.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#lab.value: The rdfs:label is used in the BDRC ontology to provide a label in the :PersonName and :WorkTitle

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.value: University of Vienna, resources for Kanjur and Tanjur studies (rKTs) reference for a rnying rgyud text

Free-text expression of the source printery for the Work.

Should be converted to a reference to a Place resource
May be used to indicate the number of introductory pages in a volume

The number of digitized metadata pages added by TBRC (now BDRC). Originally this was 2 pages and more recently condensed to a single non-blank page however a second blank page 2 was included to simplify processing of volumes for display and so on. The intention being to capture some relevant metadata in along with the digitized images so that the volume is essentially standalone.
Union class of Persons and Corporations. Used when a specific :Person or a :Corporation may be the object of a property, e.g., :eventWho on a :WorkPublished event
The organization or person that provided the Etext
THe World Bank 2000 population for the Place

The string value is formatted as a sequence of image-name:image-counts separated by the pipe, '|', character. In the normal situations the image names are incremented by one to generate image-count names.

The typical case is a collection of tiffs:

    :imageList "020640001.tif:463"

which represents images named:

    020640001.tif, 020640002.tif, 020640003.tif, . . . 020640463.tif

Volumes that have some jpeg color material will appear like:

    :imageList "I1KG9330001.tif:2|"I1KG9330003.jpg:561"

which encodes the first two TBRC metadata pages and the remainder as jpg images.

Sometimes there are volumes that are a mix of color and bitonal images, typical the front matter might be jpg and the remainder tif:

    :imageList "I2PD44320001.tif:2|I2PD44320003.jpg:3|I2PD44320006.tif:606"

There are odd naming situations where a single name stands alone and the next name is explicitly indicated:

    :imageList "1CZ7740001.tif:43|1CZ7740043a.tif|1CZ7740044.tif:472"

when a name standalone the ":1" can be dispensed with.

If this property is present it indicates that digitized images of the volume are present in the archive.

Migration hint: this property appears as <ig:description type="onDisk"/> in the source documents
Indicates that the event is known to have not occurred after to the year given
Terms of use of Etexts goes here
The license under which access to the Work is provided
The :PlaceType(s) are used to indicate a conventional characterization of a :Place, e.g., bdr:PlaceTypeBangSo, bdr:PlaceTypeChoBo, etc.

A line of Etext correponding to a line of text on a page of a physical/image asset. Lines are counted from the top of the page oriented in conventional reading orientation. Specified via line id, the starting chunk and char, and ending chunk and char.
The event of carving a set of woodblocks for a :Work
Migration hint: this is used for <o:description type="status"/>
A bibliogrpahic status statement in the language of the Work

This models the "down to ..." references to other Lineages. The other Lineage from the beginning to the holder with the same who as this holder is implicitly included with this lineage. The known use case is for the initial holder to include the prior holders from another lineage as the initial without having members of this lineage without having to repeat them. It may be meaningful to use this feature deeper in a lineage but that is not defined at this time. It is meaningful to include multiple from references which is interpreted as implicitly creating an alternative lineage for each from element.
Migration hint: Rather than a separate :personHasSeat property, the <p:seat/> is modeled as a PersonOccupiesSeat with the place and circa as for any other PersonEvent
Names are represented by rdfs:label

Lineages represent information about how a particular text or group of texts or perhaps purely oral transmission has been passed from one individual to another. The Tibetan genres, gsan yig and thob yig.

Lineage transmissions capture the relationship between lineage holders, sets of texts and the places and dates where/when the lineage was transferred from one holder to another.
use to indicate url of the original record or content (for imported records)
use for terma revelations

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#lab.value: The librarian email is used to send requests to the library staff.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.value: Loction of the publisher of the form of the Work that has been digitized.
The reference to the :ItemEtext indicates the item that contains the volume that this Etext is contained in

AccessType specifies the restrictions on access.  This is differentiated by License, which determines the legal status of copyright.  

AccessTypes desigations are intended to serve two distinct purposes: (1) maximize access of works as a public good to fulfill BDRC's mission, and (2) protect the legal and cultural rights of Tibetan authors and publishers
When, where, and by whom or what corporation a :Work was published

:ItemEtext represent the :Etext items in the archive (i.e the actual digital files). 

There are two subclasses of :ItemEtext. (1) :ItemEtextNonPaginated and (2) :ItemEtextPaginated. These are characterized by the presence or lack of pagination information maintained in the :ItemEtext. OCR is considered ItemEtextPaginated and manual input saved in RTF format  considered :ItemEtextNonPaginated. These are distinguished because there are different stuctural characteristics in the :ItemEtext.

An :ItemEtext typically will represent an entire published Work. There won't be an Etext item for each :Volume within the Work. This is because we generally want to track the entire published Work as a single entity and will use the Work :partOf Work statements along with additional statements to link an individual Etext back to a Work part.
University of Vienna, resources for Kanjur and Tanjur studies (rKTs) reference for a Tengyur text

The :VolumeImageAsset represents a scanned or otherwise digitized set of page images. These may be from paper hardcopy or microfilm. Digitization may be via scanning or camera. Going forward all of this information should be captured to reflect the provenance of the digital asset.

Each :Volume corresponds to a volume an associated :Work. A :Volume may have a :onDisk property present when the Volume has been digitized and deposited in the online archive.

Each :VolumeImageAsset may have a :imageList property which will have a '|' separated list of names of the page image files. This property is present when the subject volume has been digitized and deposited in the online archive. Otherwise, the volume will have properties related to the total number of pages, intro pages and so on as well as relevant information from the originating ScanRequest.

Alternatively, a :VolumeImageAsset may have an :hasManifest property that identifies an :IIIFManifest resource. This will typically occur when the images associated with the :VolumeImageAsset are served from a third-party IIIF server.

Further, the :imageList property will be deprecated in favor of :hasDimensionData which will represent the image specific, name, height and width that is needed to generate a IIIF Manifest on-the-fly. The dimension data is a json array of per image data.
this property refers to a named IIIF Manifest resource. The resource may be local or at another location such as the British Library EAP
true
International Standard Book Number.

Used as a reference from a :VolumeEtextAsset to a particular :Etext, via :eTextResource, and indicating the position, :seqNum, of the :Etext in the volume.

This work is a derivative of the reference work. This means that it may be a later edition or a version with some "corrections"/changes to the content of the referenced work.

For example,

bdr:W30532 :workDerivativeOf bdr:W22084

bdr:W30532 is a printing based on woodblocks that have a variety of "corrections" made via plugs in the original woodblocks and W22084 is a printing from the original sde dge Kanjur woodblocks so it makes sense to indicate that bdr:W30532 is a derivative of bdr:W22084.

the code attribute records a unique 3-latin-letter code for the Library. For example, DZL would be reasonable for Dzongsar Library. The code along with the num attribute are used to create RIDs for Works that are added by the library. RIDs will take the form of: W1TLMDZL000001
Associates modern address information with a Place

The license varies among the different parts of the work. For example, some part of a work may be under copyright (i.e. a work containing a contemporary introduction) and the remaining parts may be in the Public Domain (i.e. an orginial 19th century work re-typed).
language of a :LangScript
In the Tang Dynasty (618-907), the Chinese dynasty and the national dynasty shared a total of 289 years with 21 emperors

A digitized set of pages, one per page (folio side), produced by document scanning, digital photography.  The resulting set of assets in :ItemImageAsset are images in a wide variety of archival and derivative formats.

In some cases volumes of a :Work are given names. For example, in Tibetan a three volume work might have volumes named O, a, huM or a 10 volume work might have volumes named: ka, kha, ga, nga, ca, cha, ja, nya, ta, a.

This describes the material on which the content of a :TextualEntity is imposed.
Timer periods are specified in terms of year ranges via :notBefore and :notAfter. Years are signed integers using Western "Common Era" reckoning.
Name of containing province in pinyin per Karl Ryavec for import of historical places
one of sa ngor tsar gsum

This serves as a blank node that represents an actual volume corresponding to a volume of a printed/pubished Work OR a virtual volume of all of the eTexts contained in a printed/published Work.

The ambiguity arises because in some cases we do not have know the actual volume or volume order of a collection of input eTexts that have been provided for preservation. 

An example is the Guru Lama collection of Sakyapa eTexts. These were all input and used to prepare printed pechas that were distributed but when the files were supplied the correspondence of files to volumes and the order of the files in volumes was not provided. Therefor we have simply represented each Work as a single virtual volume with a collection of files in some order. Later it should be possible to analyze these particular Works to establish the volume and order within volume of the various eTexts by examining the titles and so on.

There is no distinction between OCR'd and input volumes.
Identifies the type and person that are a creator of the work

The source path, for an InputEtext, is a relative to an unspecified file system root and identifies a file from which the Unicode eText was generated. This should be the original Tibet Doc, Sambhota Word or other input format.

For an OCR file this should refer to the file generated by the OCR process which contains information regarding character positioning and so on.
Refers to the Library of Congress Control Number

This is a reference to what is being transmitted in the :Lineage. Typically this is a deity, ritual, or teaching or some sort. The :lineageType will indicate the nature of the :Lineage transmission, empowerment, reading transmission, instructions on practice and so on.

The object should be restricted to Persons or to Topics that represent a Deity or other suitable objects of a Lineage (what might those be?). This requires a union of some sort.
Reference number from Skorupski's catalogue
International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration, used to translitterate indic languages like Sanskrit, Pali, Hindi, etc.

Refers to a page of an eText corresponding to a physical/image page asset.

Used to provide stand-off markup for the pagination of eText in correspondence with physical/image assets when known such as in OCR or certain cases of manual input where such information has been preserved during input.
associates an event with a time period

This is the number of volumes (if any) associated with the Work. Typically this is for a published work. The value may differ from the "actual" number of volumes in an associated Item owing to missing volumes.

A transliteration used to represent a language in a non-native script. For example, ExtendWylie transliteration of Tibetan written in Latin script, or Pinyin a Romanization of Chinese (in Latin script)

LineageType identifies the type of lineage transmission being documented. Examples are empowerment, instruction, reading transmission, etc.
The quality of the scanning or eText conversion to poor to warrant making it available online.
Range should be unionOf Person and Deity(Topics)

original XSD has "RID" attr in "Received"
Some might not count Rime as a Tradition but since there are Works and Persons who are identified as such it is approapriate to include for purposes of classification
The prodcutAllowByAddr has an xsd:string with the format of a cidr IP address range, e.g., 128.2.8.0/24. These address ranges are used to permit access to collections of works
names are represented via bdo:PersonName

The Person object tracks biographical data such as kinship relations, birth and death dates, administrative offices  and seats held, important events and known name variants.  Instances of Person objects are not created for historical and quasi-historical personages, including legendary and mythical figures. Deities are defined as Topics.
Pali in Thai script
The source person.xsd includes event/pid which is not used and should be silently discarded during migration.
Identifies an event that occurred at this Place, e.g., founded, rebuilt, deserted, etc.
identifies who this :LineageHolder is, :Person or a being represented via a :Topic.
A manuscript written by the hand of the author
Token or name that is associated with a resource, such as a URI or an ISBN.  A resource that is associated with a character string that serves to differentiate one resource from another.
The score associated with a statement, assessing its likelihood. Unlikely statements should have a negative score.
The subject is a volume of the referenced item.
the admin:Product contains the referenced :Work
:TextualEntity is a subclass of :Work, or :Item or :Etext that is constructed so that the adm:license range can be applied across
A positive integer indicating the total number of images in the VolumeImageAsset
can be v2.1.* or v3.0.*
position of the eText in the volume that contains it

Shey Palace manuscript reference number
Place ID assigned by Karl Ryavec used for import of historical Tibetan place information. This id is based on an old GB code and is not current. It will be removed in the future from the data set
use for the main title on the title page (not the cover page) when it differs from the bibliographical title.
The subject work is identified as a translation of the referenced work. This will be used, for example, when the subject work is a Tibetan translation of a referenced Sanskrit work.
use for the title on the copyright page when it differs from the bibliographical title.
The area in square km of the Place from the World Bank 2010
Modern or contemporary places defined in terms of current political control such as Chinese counties, provinces and so on

NB: The definition of <w:info/> in work.xsd is incorrect since it allows unbounded use of <w:info/>. It should have been spec'd as only 1 occurrence. Hence in the ontology the wrk:info properties have domain wrk:Work rather than introducing an anon class
Note that <archiveInfo/> @distribution and @restriction are not used and not migrated. They have been replaced by @license and access.

The wrk:Work resource models the descriptive metadata about a "book" in the BUDAverse. The legacy model split the descriptive metadata between Works and Pubinfos ( predominantly publication data). Thisr ontology merges the Work and Pubinfo items under the wrk:Work resource so there is no hasPubinfo property.

The Works also included some structural metadata in the volumeMap but that is moved to the vol:Volumes resource in this ontology.
An event associated with the production of a :Work. Event information is gathered from colophons and publication data presented in the publishede form of texts
An event of preparing a written manuscript of a Work
If the subject Work :isPartOf another work then the referenced part type reflects the type of part: chapter, section, volume, etc
Id and indication that the Work was prepared and acquired as part of Gene Smith's contribution to the implementation of Public Law 480 in India in the 1960's and 70's
the :workLocation may be used with other domains and these will be added in an owl:unionOf as they are added. One such is expected to be :Note
This is the location of the source information for this :Lineage in a specified gsan / thob yig.
Starting chunk:char of a page, line, or other slice

The source person.xsd includes @type on <info/> which is meant to capture whether the Person is an "actor" in the world of Tibetan books. There are 40 out of 18,320 individuals that have been marked as info/@type = nonActor. These 40 are non-Tibetan individuals that have been included in the db because they are translators, or authors of some work of interest. Many of the records of nonActors have various small errors that need to be corrected.

In any event, when a per:Person is being migrated with info/@type = nonactor then simply assert:  p? :personNonActor true, and we will be able to locate these individuals after migration for further attention

Mixed access is used on a work or Item to indicate that the access on parts may vary. E.g., some part of a work may be provided under the Fair Use exception (a contemporary introduction) and the remaining parts may be Open (for content published in the 18th century), except for a part marked as restricted by tradition.
the object of :lineageHolder is a :LineageHolder that describes an individual that held the given :Lineage
